Dear ELEANOR LOUISE MARQUIS:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 2/26/2024-3/1/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
PA 116 722.120(10)(3) C onfidentiality
(3) records regarding children and facts compiled about
children and their parents and relatives are confidential
and disclosure of this information must be properly
safeguarded by the childcare organization, the
department, and any other entity in possession of the
information. Records that are confidential under this
section are available to 1 or more of the following:
1 of 8 foster home files reviewed (6 open, 2 closed) contained a Special Evaluation
Report documenting confidential information, including the involvement and findings
of CPS-MIC.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 3/3/2023, CAP Approved 3/20/2023
CPA Rule 400.12325 License recommendation.
(1) An agency shall recommend to the department the
appropriate licensing action consistent with facts
contained in the foster home evaluation and any
special evaluations.
1 of 8 foster home files reviewed (6 open, 2 closed) contained a Special Evaluation

Report documenting an additional foster home violation was observed during a
home visit (a youth's bedroom door had been removed;) however, the additional
violation was not established.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 3/11/2022, CAP Approved 3/25/2022
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(4) Before completion of the written report required by
subrule (6) of this rule, an agency shall provide the foster
parent with a verbal summary of the preliminary findings
at the conclusion of the evaluation.
4 of 8 foster home files reviewed (6 open, 2 closed) included Special Evaluation
Reports documenting the verbal summary of preliminary findings was provided to the
foster parent prior to the conclusion of the investigation.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
(e) A dental examination must be
completed within 3 months before entry into
foster care or an initial dental examination
must be completed not more than 90
calendar days after entry into a foster care
out-of-home placement. A child entering
foster care under 1 year of age must have
an initial dental exam within 3 months of his
or her first birthday.
1 of 8 open files of youth in foster care placements contained documentation
verifying the initial dental examination was not completed timely.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of Placement
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child’s record before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the
new placement, consistent with the requirements
of R 400.12417.
1 of 8 open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain documentation

of all required information being provided to the caregiver at replacement (typically
documented on the DHS 3307 and DHS 3762
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Cited as R 400.12417 (a-h), Interim 3/3/2023, CAP Approved 3/20/2023
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(h) If parental rights have not been terminated, the
service plan must include all the following:
(e) Documentation of how the parents were informed of
their rights and responsibilities in the care of their child.
1 of 8 open files of youth in foster care placements did not contain documentation

development (typically documented on the DHS 5307).
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact.
(2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child’s
placement at least once every month.
2 of 8 open files of youth in foster care placements did not document once a month
face to face visits in the foster home with the youth and foster parent. Both youths
were initially placed on 9/7/2023 and neither youth had visits documented to take
place in the foster home that month. All visits in subsequent month occurred, as
required.
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service
worker and the youth in independent living at least
once each month at a youth's place of residence.

documentation that the required visits took place with the youth in the youth's
placement in June, July, September or December of 2023 or January of 2024.

F OM 722-06B F AMILY TEAM MEETING

FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement or
no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business
days of the FTM.
3 of 10 open youth files reviewed (8 foster care, 2 independent living) did not
contain documentation of all FTMs being held, as required. The missing/late FTMs
were related to placements changes and service plan development.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 3/11/2022, CAP Approved 3/25/2022
Interim 3/3/2023, CAP Approved 3/20/2023
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
S IGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart.

• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:
• I have participated in the development of the
Case Service Plan and the Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service
Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to
review, and I will have the opportunity to express
my disagreement with the Case Service Plan and
Parent Agency Treatment Plan when the
information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify,
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the
electronic case record within 30 days of the report date.
7 of 10 open youth files reviewed (8 foster care, 2 independent living) contained
Parent Agency Treatment Plans either missing required signatures or documented
signatures were not requested/obtained timely. This represented 15 of 33 PATPs
reviewed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 3/11/2022, CAP Approved 3/25/2022
Interim 3/3/2023, CAP Approved 3/20/2023
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
• The new rules identify topics that must be covered during foster parent
training. The majority of the hours completed for one foster parent were
Hollywood movies. If Hollywood movies are determined to provide some
training, they must cover the required training topics. Additionally, there must

be an assessment of how many actual training hours are received from the
movie and not just count the runtime of the film.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Re-assess how document uploads are being monitored as several documents
were uploaded within the week prior to or during the inspection.
• Reminder that all renewal/annual foster home evaluation visits and reports
must be completed annually/within 365 days of the previous visit/ report.
Additionally, all renewal report recommendation must be made to the
department at least 15 days before the license expiration.
• Foster home variances for non-compliances learned during special
evaluations or annual foster home assessments are requires on a case
specific basis. Every non-compliance resulting in a CAP does not
automatically require a variance request.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were 2 incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. Both of the SER's related to corporal punishment were reviewed and found to
be completed thoroughly and timely. Both included appropriate recommendations
based on the findings.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. In 2022,
the agency was cited for 9 violations, 4 of which were repeated this year. Of those
4, there was an improvement in individual incidents of non-compliance within 2 of
the violation areas and a slight increase in number of individual incidents in the
other 2 areas. In 2023, 12 violations were established, 7 of which were repeated
this year. All of the repeated violations remain close to the name number of
individual incidents of non-compliances. The agency will need to establish
additional corrective planning for the repeated violations to ensure a reduction of
incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was discussed during the entrance meeting.
The chief administrator accurately identified areas in which agency staff were non-
compliant due to performance issues, new staff training, and unexpected staff
leave.
Financial Overview
Not applicable as this is an MDHHS office.

Staff Interviews
All the staff interviewed reported their immediate supervisors are knowledgeable,
supportive, and helpful. They all indicated they participate in regular and frequent
supervision and team meeting and are provided with training opportunities
throughout the year. They all expressed being informed of policy or rule change
requirements timely.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency has the space and equipment needed to perform job requirements.
The files are stored securely to prevent unauthorized access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
